briefOverview: The revelation reaffirms the First Presidency’s priesthood keys and commissions them to preside, receive oracles, and set the Church in order. It adds practical directives for church governance, missionary scope, temporal stewardship, and correction regarding Zion.
summary: The Lord forgives Joseph Smith and confirms that he holds the keys of the kingdom, through whom divine oracles will be given to the Church; recipients are warned not to treat these oracles lightly. Sidney Rigdon and Frederick G. Williams are also forgiven and declared equal with Joseph in holding the keys, including oversight of the School of the Prophets to perfect ministers for Zion, Israel, and the Gentiles; the word will go to the Gentiles first and later to the Jews, and eventually all will hear the gospel in their own language by the Comforter’s power. Joseph is commanded to continue in the presidency, finish the translation of the prophets, preside over church and school affairs, receive revelations, set the churches in order, and diligently study languages and good books—his lifelong mission. Admonitions follow against pride, sloth, and uncleanness, with counsel to set homes in order. Practical instructions include providing for Frederick G. Williams’s family, keeping Joseph Smith Sr. and Sidney Rigdon in their current residences until directed otherwise, and appointing a faithful, well-resourced agent to discharge debts so the Lord’s storehouse maintains a good reputation. The Saints are urged to pray, believe, walk uprightly, and keep families small with respect to dependents outside the household so resources are not diverted to the unworthy. Vienna Jaques is directed to go to Zion, receive expenses and an inheritance, and consecrate the remainder; Zion is told to accept the First Presidency’s future role to preside, to repent, and to expect the Lord’s chastening until she is clean, with the promise she shall not be removed out of her place.
externalContext: This revelation is dated to March 1833 in Kirtland, Ohio, where Joseph Smith had recently organized the First Presidency (Joseph Smith, Sidney Rigdon, and Frederick G. Williams). The “School of the Prophets,” organized in early 1833, was designed to train church leaders in doctrine and practical knowledge, including languages and scripture. Joseph Smith’s ongoing “translation of the prophets” refers to his Bible revision (often called the Joseph Smith Translation), particularly work on Old Testament prophetic books at that time. “Zion” here points to Jackson County, Missouri, designated by church leaders as a central gathering place; rising tensions with local Missourians would soon escalate later in 1833. Vienna Jaques was an early Latter-day Saint benefactor; Sidney Gilbert served as a church agent and merchant in Independence, Missouri, and Newel K. Whitney functioned as a bishop overseeing the church’s storehouse and temporal affairs.
externalReferences: Language about “keys of the kingdom” echoes Jesus’ words to Peter in Matthew 16:19, and the term “oracles” recalls Paul’s reference to the “oracles of God” entrusted to Israel in Romans 3:2. The warning about storms beating upon a house parallels Jesus’ parable of the wise and foolish builders in Matthew 7:24–27. The vision of all peoples hearing the gospel in their own tongue resonates with Pentecost in Acts 2:6–11, and the phrase “arm of the Lord” being revealed recalls Isaiah 52:10. The charge to “set in order” the churches aligns with Paul’s mandate to Titus to set things in order in Crete (Titus 1:5), while the sequence “to the Gentiles first, then to the Jews” contrasts with the New Testament pattern of “to the Jew first” (Romans 1:16).
practicalQuestions: How do I treat prophetic counsel and scripture so it is not a “light thing” in my life?
What disciplines of study (languages, good books, people) would better equip me for my spiritual and leadership responsibilities?
Where might pride or sloth be undermining my home or stewardship, and how can I set things in order?
How can my community manage debts and resources transparently to avoid bringing the Lord’s work into disrepute?
What would it look like today to prioritize preaching to all nations and tongues while also remembering Israel and the Jews?
uncertainAreas: “The keys shall never be taken from you” could refer to Joseph Smith personally or to the continuing office he represents; the text doesn’t explicitly clarify. “Through you shall the oracles be given to another” likely means to the Church collectively, but the mechanism is not detailed. The counsel to keep families “small” as to those not belonging to your families may refer to limiting boarders or dependents, yet the exact application is unclear. The promise that Zion will not be removed is difficult to reconcile with later 1833 events in Jackson County and may be conditional or forward-looking; the text does not specify timing or conditions.
